newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP expected to raise 1996 dividend.
newsitem.headline: SAP expected to raise 1996 dividend.

text.p: German business software group SAP AG is likely to announce an increase in dividends when it presents consolidated 1996 results next week, analysts said on Monday.

Pointing to a surprisingly robust fourth quarter, analysts contacted by Reuters said they expected SAP to propose a dividend of 1.65 to 1.80 marks per common share, up from the 1995 dividned of 1.30 marks.
The analysts forecast preferred share dividends of 1.70 to 1.85 marks, up from 1.35 in 1995.

Heinz Steffen of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson Resesarch expected SAP to propose a common share dividend of 1.65 marks and to award one bonus share for every five shares to celebrate the company's 25th anniversary year.
Others, like Heinz Weyerhauser at DG Bank DGBG.g.F saw an anniversary bonus combined into higher dividends. Weyerhaeser predicted a common share dividend of 1.70 marks.

SAP shares were up four marks in floor trading at 279.50 marks, helped by reports that U.S. auto maker General Motors Corp was considering a "billion dollar" implementation of SAP's R/3 software, which businesses use to monitor manufacturing, purchasing, payroll and acounting data.
Sales for 1996 rose 38 percent to 3.7 billion marks, with net income climbing 40 percent to 567 million marks, after a strong finish more than offset a weak third quarter.
SAP last week told Reuters sales in the first quarter of 1997 were running according to expectations.
"We have said we expect sales to grow 25 to 30 percent and pretax profit to increase at a slightly faster rate, by a few percentage points," management board member Henning Kagermann said.
But he also said that most of the quarter's sales would be booked in March. "The last month of the quarter always has the most business," he said. The next weeks will tell."
